dtl_desc: TO TABLE A POINT OF ORDER, RAISED DURING DEBATE ON PROCEEDING TO CONSIDERATION OF S. RES.6, WHICH AMENDS SENATE RULE 22.  SENATOR MC GOVERN MOVED TO CLOSE DEBATE ON TAKING UP S. RES. 6 BY A SIMPLE MAJORITY, CITING ARTICLE I, SECTION 5 OF THE CONSTITUT2ON.  SEN. DIRKSEN MADE THE POINT OF ORDER THAT THIS WAS NOT A CONSTITUTIONAL QUESTION, AND MC GOVERN WAS, IN EFFECT, MOVING THE PREVIOUS QUESTION BY A SIMPLE, RATHER THAN A 2/3 MAJORITY, AS REQUIRED BY THE RULES.

TO DECIDE A POINT OF ORDER, MADE DURING DEBATE ON WHETHER TO TAKE UP S. RES. 6, WHICH AMENDS SENATE RULE 22. SEN. MC GOVERN MOVED TO CLOSE DEBATE ON PROCEEDING TO CONSIDERATION OF S. RES. 6 BY MAJORITY VOTE, CITING ARTICLE I, SEC. 5 OF THE CONSTITUTION.  SEN. DIRKSEN RAISED THE POINT OF ORDER THAT A CONSTITUTIONAL QUESTION WAS NOT RAISED, AND THAT THE PREVIOUS QUESTION REQUIRED A 2/3 MAJORITY.
TO IMPOSE CLOTURE ON DEBATE ON S. RES. 6, WHICH AMENDS RULE 22 OF THE SENATE, BY REQUIRING A 3/5 RATHER THAN 2/3 MAJORITY TO IMPOSE CLOTURE.
TO AMEND S. 355, THE LEGISLATIVE REORGANIZATION ACT OF 1967, BY PROVIDING FOR THE INSTALLATION OF A PUBLIC ADDRESS SYSTEM WITHIN THE SENATE CHAMBER.

TO TABLE AN AMENDMENT TO S. 355, WHICH WOULD ADD 3-5 EX-OFFICIO MEMBERS TO THE COMM. ON APPROPRIATIONS.  THE ADDITIONAL MEMBERS WOULD BE CHOSEN FROM COMMITTEES NOT ALREADY REPRESENTED BY EX-OFFICIO MEMBERS.
TO AMEND S. 355, BY ELIMINATING THE PRACTICE OF EX-OFFICIO SITTING ON THE APPROPRIATIONS COMM.

TO TABLE AN AMENDMENT TO S. 355, OFFERED BY SENATOR CLARK, WHICH ABOLISHES THE RIGHT TO REQUIRE READING ALOUD OF THE JOURNAL, UNLESS UNANIMOUS CONSENT TO THE CONTRARY IS GIVEN. THE AMENDMENT ALSO PROPOSES THAT THE SENATE PART OF THE CONGRESSIONAL RECORD BE CONSTRUED AS THE SENATE JOURNAL WHICH THE CONSTITUTION OF THE U.S. REQUIRES THE SENATE TO TO KEEP.

TO TABLE AN AMENDMENT TO S. 355, WHICH AMENDMENT FORBIDS ANY EMPLOYEE OR MEMBER OF THE SENATE TO ENGAGE IN ANY REGULAR PROFESSIONAL OR CONSULTING PRACTICE, OR TO SERVE IN ANY MANAGERIAL CAPACITY IN ANY BUSINESS OR FINANCIAL ENTERPRISE WITHOUT SPECIAL LEAVE OF THE SENATE.
TO TABLE AN AMENDMENT TO S. 355, WHICH PROVIDES FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A SELECT COMMITTEE ON SMALL BUSINESS, WITH "LEGISLATIVE AUTHORITY."
TO RECOMMIT S. 355, FOR 30 DAYS OF FURTHER STUDY.
TO AMEND S. 355, TO ALLOW COMMITTEES TO CONTINUE THE PRESENT PRACTICE OF ALLOWING SENATORS TO VOTE BY PROXY, IN COMMITTEE.

TO AMEND S. 355, BY PERMITTING COMMITTEES TO SIT FOR ANY PURPOSE WHILE THE SENATE IS IN SESSION WITH PERMISSION OF MAJORITY AND MINORITY LEADERS.  UNDER PRESENT PRACTICE, PERMISSION OF THE WHOLE SENATE IS REQUIRED, AND S. 355 PROVIDES THAT COMMITTEES MAY SIT WITH PERMISSION OF LEADERSHIP ONLY TO CONDUCT HEARINGS.
TO AMEND S. 355, BY DELETING THE LANGUAGE WHICH ALLOWS COMITTEES TO SIT WHILE SENATE IS IN SESSION WITH PERMISSION OF MAJORITY AND MINORITY LEADERS.

TO TABLE AN AMENDMENT TO S. 355, WHICH WOULD REQUIRE SENATORS TO FILE FULL FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND INCOME TAX RETURNS WITH THE COMPTROLLER-GENERAL; PENALTIES FOR FILING FALSE STATEMENTS WOULD BE THE SAME AS THOSE FOR FILING FALSE INCOME TAX RETURNS.  THIS AMENDMENT WAS OFFERED BY SEN. WILLIAMS OF DELAWARE.
TO TABLE AN AMENDMENT TO S. 355, REQUIRING FULL DISCLOSURE OF ASSETS, LIABILITIES AND BUSINESS CONNECTIONS OF SENATOR. THIS AMENDMENT WAS OFFERED BY SEN. CLARK.

TO TABLE AN AMENDMENT TO S. 355, WHICH FORBIDS ANY MEMBER OR ANY OFFICER OR EMPLOYEE OF THE SENATE TO ACCEPT AT ANY TIME FROM ANY INDIVIDUAL, ENTITY, OR ENTERPRISE WHICH IS ENGAGED IN LOBBYING ACTIVITY, ANY GIFT OF MONEY, PROPERTY, ENTERTAINMENT, TRAVEL, OR ANY OTHER VALUABLE CONSIDERATION VALUED IN EXCESS OF $100.
TO AMEND S. 355, BY VIRTUALLY ELIMINATING THE PRACTICE OF CO-SPONSORING BILLS.
TO AMEND S. RES. 21, A BILL TO PROVIDE 6 ADDITIONAL STAFF MEMBERS FOR THE COMMITTEE ON FINANCE, BY REDUCING THE NUMBER OF ADDITIONAL STAFF TO 4.
TO PASS H.R. 4573, A BILL TO PROVIDE A PERMANENT INCREASE IN THE PUBLIC DEBT LIMIT.

TO AGREE TO CONFERENCE REPORT ON H.R. 4573, A BILL TO PROVIDE AN INCREASE IN THE PUBLIC DEBT LIMIT.  AS PASSED BY THE SENATE, THE NEW CEILING OF $336 BILLION WAS PERMANENT. AS PASSED BY THE HOUSE, THE CEILING WAS TEMPORARY, AND THE HOUSE VERSION PREVAILED IN CONFERENCE.

TO RATIFY THREE FISHERIES TREATIES, DEALING RESPECTIVELY WITH FISHERY RESOURCES IN NORTHEASTERN ATLANTIC, INCREASING THE SIZE OF COMMISSION ON GREAT LAKES FISHING AND A COMMISSION TO FORMULATE MEASURES FOR CONSERVATION OF TUNA.
TO RATIFY 2 TREATIES WHICH REDUCE AND STANDARDIZE THE NUMBER OF PAPERS THAT SHIPS MUST LEAVE WITH AUTHORITIES ON ENTERING AND LEAVING PORTS.
TO RATIFY SEVERAL TREATIES, EN BLOC, WHICH MAKE EASIER THE TEMPORARY IMPORTATION OF CERTAIN EQUIPMENT, AND HAVE THE COMMON AIM OF FACILILATING INTERNATIONAL TRADE.

TO AMEND S. 665, AUTHORIZING SUPPLEMENTAL APPROPRIATIONS FOR ARMED FORCES.  THE AMENDMENT ON WHICH THE ROLL CALL IS TAKEN WAS OFFERED BY SEN. MANSFIELD AS A SUBSTITUTE FOR AN AMENDMENT OFFERED BY SEN. CLARK.  IN SENATOR MANSFIELD'S AMENDMENT, THE SENATE DECLARES ITS SUPPORT FOR THE GENEVA ACCORDS OF 1954 AND 1962, AND URGES THE CONVENING OF THAT CONFERENCE OR ANY OTHER MEETING OF NATIONS SIMILARLY INVOLVED, FOR THE PURPOSE OF FORMULATING PLANS FOR BRINGING THE CONFLICT TO AN HONORABLE CONCLUSION.

TO AMEND S. 665.  THE VOTE IS ON AN AMENDMENT OFFERED BY CLARK, WHICH WAS ITSELF AMENDED BY SUBSTITUTING THE MANSFIELD AMENDMENT, URGING THAT THE GENEVA CONFERENCE BE RECALLED AS SOON AS POSSIBLE TO FORMULATE PLANS FOR ENDING THE VIETNAM CONFLICT.
TO PASS S. 665.

TO TABLE AN AMENDMENT TO S. 355, LEGISLATIVE REORGANIZATION ACT OF 1967, WHICH PROVIDES THAT WHENEVER A SENATOR HAS HELD THE FLOOR FOR 3 CONSECUTIVE HOURS, AN OBJECTION TO HIS CONTINUED POSSESSION OF THE FLOOR, IF MADE BY ANY SENATOR, WOULD COMPEL HIM TO YIELD THE FLOOR.

TO TABLE AN AMENDMENT (NO. 12) TO S. 355, WHICH AMENDMENT STATES THAT, DURING CONSIDERATION OF ANY MATTER, ANY SENATOR MAY MOVE THAT ALL FURTHER DEBATE BE GERMANE.  THE MOTION WOULD BE NON-DEBATEABLE.
TO TABLE AN AMENDMENT (NO. 13) TO S. 355, WHICH INCORPORATES INTO THE STANDING RULES OF THE SENATE A GENERAL PROHIBITION AGAINST NON-GERMANE AMENDMENTS.

TO TABLE AN AMENDMENT (NO. 31) TO S. 355, WHICH REPEALS RULE 22 OF THE SENATE, AND SUBSTITUTES A RULE WHICH WOULD ALLOW PREVIOUS QUESTION TO BE CALLED FOR BY A MAJORITY OF SENATORS PRESENT AND VOTING; FIRST, WHEN ANY MOTION OR AMENDMENT HAD RECEIVED 15 HOURS OF CONSIDERATION ON NOT LESS THAN 3 CALENDER DAYS, OR SECOND, ON THE MEASURE ITSELF, AND ALL RELATED AMENDMENTS, AFTER IT HAD RECEIVED CONSIDERATION FOR 15 CALENDER DAYS.

TO TABLE AN AMENDMENT TO S. 355, WHICH PROVIDES THAT ALL MOTIONS TO PROCEED TO CONSIDERATION OF ANY MATTER ARE DEBATEABLE, PROVIDED THAT ANY SENATOR MAY FILE A NOTICE OF INTENTION TO CONSIDER ANY MATTER ON THE SENATE CALENDER ON THE FOLLOWING CALENDER DAY ON WHICH SENATE IS IN SESSION. THE FILING OF SUCH NOTICE SHALL AUTOMATICALLY LIMIT DEBATE ON MOTION TO PROCEED TO 1 HOUR.

TO TABLE AN AMENDMENT TO S. 355, WHICH AUTHORIZES RAISES IN SALARY FOR PROFESSIONAL STAFFS ON SENATE COMMITTEES, TO BRING SALARIES UP TO GS-18 LEVELS, AND TO MAKE THEM EQUIVALENT TO HOUSE COMMITTEE STAFF SALARIES.
TO AMEND S. 355, BY AUTHORIZING SALARY INCREASES FOR THE PROFESSIONAL STAFF OF SENATE COMMITTEES, TO BRING SALARIES UP TO G.S. 18 LEVELS AND TO MAKE THEM EQUIVALENT TO HOUSE COMMITTEE STAFF SALARIES.
TO TABLE AN AMENDMENT TO S. 355, WHICH PROVIDES FOR A LEGISLATIVE ATTOURNEY-GENERAL FOR CONGRESS.

TO AMEND S. 355, BY EXTENDING TO THE COMM. ON FOREIGN RELATIONS CERTAIN PRIVILEGES WHICH ARE PRESENTLY EXTENDED ONLY TO THE COMMITTEE ON APPROPRIATIONS, INVOLVING PROCEDURES FOR SELECTING COMMITTEE STAFF, SHORTER ADVANCE NOTICE OF COMMITTEE HEARINGS, AND THE PRIVILEGE OF NOT ANNOUNCING VOTES IN COMMITTEE, AMONG OTHERS.
TO AMEND S. 355, BY STRIKING OUT THOSE PROVISIONS WHICH AUTHORIZE OR REQUIRE ADDITIONAL STAFF FOR COMMITTEES.
TO AMEND S. 355, BY STRIKING THE PROVISION FOR AN ADDITIONAL LEGISLATIVE ASSISTANT FOR EACH SENATOR, THE FUNDS FOR WHICH ARE NOT TO COME FROM REGULAR AMOUNT ALLOTTED TO SENATORS FOR OTHER EMPLOYEES.
TO AMEND S. 355, BY MAKING HOUSE AND SENATE PROFESSIONAL STAFF SALARIES EQUAL, TO BE ACCOMPLISHED BY REDUCING THE AMOUNT THAT HOUSE CAN PAY TOP EMPLOYEES FROM $25,890 TO $24,460.

TO AMEND S. 355, BY NOT REQUIRING COMMITTEES TO SUBMIT AN ANNUAL REVIEW OF THEIR ACTIVITIES, IF THEY HAVE NOT APPOINTED THE REVIEW SPECIALIST TO WHICH EACH COMMITTEE, UNDER THE PROVISIONS OF S. 355, IS ENTITLED.

TO AMEND S. 355, BY PROVIDING THAT THE STATIONARY ALLOWANCE FOR MEMBERS OF THE HOUSE AND SENATE BE USED ONLY FOR STATIONARY AND OFFICE SUPPLIES AND THAT ANY PART NOT SO USED BE RETURNED TO THE TREASURY.

TO AMEND S. 355, BY DELETING TITLE V, WHICH CALLS FOR DEFERRING ACTION ON AMENDING THE FEDERAL REGULATIONS OF LOBBYING ACT UNTIL A MORE THOROUGH AND COMPLETE PLAN OF REVISION OF THAT ACT CAN BE PLACED BEFORE THE CONGRESS; SUCH A REVISION TO BE PLACED BEFORE CONGRESS AT AN EARLY DATE, AND IS NOW IN PREPARATION BY DEPT. OF JUSTICE.
TO AMEND S. 355, BY PROVIDING FOR FREE GUIDE SERVICE FOR VISITORS TO THE CAPITOL BUILDING.
TO PASS S. 355, THE LEGISLATIVE REORGANIZATION ACT OF 1967.
TO AMEND A CONSULAR CONVENTION WITH THE U.S.S.R., BY DELETING A PROVISION FOR IMMUNITY FROM CRIMINAL JURISDICTION FOR SOVIET CONSULAR OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES.
TO AGREE TO EXECUTIVE RESERVATION NO. 1 TO EXEC. D, WHICH PROVIDES THAT THE CONVENTION SHALL NOT GO INTO EFFECT UNTIL THE U.S.S.R. AGREES TO CERTAIN CONDITIONS INVOLVING FREEDOM OF THE PRESS

TO AGREE TO EXECUTIVE RESERVATION NO. 2 TO EX.D, PROVIDING THAT A CONSULAR CONVENTION WITH THE SOVIET UNION WILL NOT TAKE EFFECT UNTIL THE PRESIDENT ADVISES THE CONGRESS THAT THE WAR IN VIETNAM IS OVER, OR, THAT THE WITHDRAWAL OF COMBAT TROOPS FROM VIETNAM IS NOT BEING DELAYED BECAUSE OF MILITARY ASSISTANCE FURNISHED NORTH VIETNAM BY THE U.S.S.R.

TO AGREE TO EXECUTIVE RESERVATION NUMBER 3 TO EXECUTIVE D, PROVIDING THAT THE TREATY SHALL NOT BECOME EFFECTIVE UNTIL THE PRESIDENT, AFTER CONSULTATION WITH THE JOINT CHIEFS OF STAFF, REPORTS TO THE CONGRESS THAT THE SOVIET UNION HAS CEASED ALL MILITARY SUPPORT AND ASSISTANCE TO NORTH VIETANM.

TO AGREE TO EXECUTIVE RESERVATION NUMBER 4 TO EXECUTIVE D, ADDING THE FOLLOWING LANGUAGE TO THE CONVENTION.  "NOTHING IN THIS CONVENTION SHALL BE CONSTRUED AS IN ANY WAY DIMINISHING, ABRIDGING, OR WEAKENING THE RIGHT OF THE UNITED STATES TO SAFEGUARD ITS OWN SECURITY."

TO AGREE TO EXECUTIVE UNDERSTANDING NO. 1, WITH REFERENCE TO EXECUTIVE D.  THE UNDERSTANDING ADDS TO THE RESOLUTION OF RATIFICATION THE HOPE OF THE SENATE THAT BEFORE THE U.S. CONSENTS TO THE OPENING BY THE SOVIET UNION OF ANY CONSULAR ESTABLISHMENT IN THE U.S., THE CONFLICT IN VIETNAM BE HONORABLY CONCLUDED.

TO RATIFY EXEC. D, A CONSULAR CONVENTION WITH THE SOVIET UNION WHICH REGULATES THE CONSULAR AFFAIRS OF EACH COUNTRY IN THE TERRITORY OF THE OTHER, AND THE TREATMENT TO BE ACCORDED TO CONSULAR OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES.  IT PROVIDES THAT WHEN A NATIONAL OF A "SENDING" COUNTRY IS ARRESTED IN A "RECEIVING" COUNTRY, COUNSULAR OFFICERS OF THE "SENDING" COUNTRY MUST BE NOTIFIED WITHIN 1-3 DAYS, AND CERTAIN VISITING PRIVILEGES MUST BE ALLOWED.  FURTHER, COUSULAR OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES OF THE "SENDING" STATE WILL BE IMMUNE FROM CRIMINAL PROSECUTION OF THE "RECEIVING" STATE.
TO PASS H.R. 7123, A BILL TO PROVIDE $12 BILLION IN ADDITIONAL FUNDS FOR SUPPORT OF MILITARY OPERATIONS IN SOUTHEAST ASIA.
TO PASS S. 666, A BILL AUTHORIZING $20 BILLION FOR PROCUREMENT OF HARDWARE FOR ALL BRANCHES OF THE ARMED SERVICES.
TO RATIFY EXEC E, A SAFETY-AT-SEA-TREATY, REQUIRING HIGHER FIRE SAFETY STANDARDS ON PASSENGER VESSELS.

TO PASS S.J. RES. 65, A RESOLUTION EXTENDING THE PROVISIONS OF EXISTING LAW PROHIBITING, FOR A LIMITED TIME, STRIKES AND CHANGES IN THE WORK RULES INVOLVED IN THIS RAILWAY LABOR DISPUTE FOR AN ADDITIONAL 20 DAYS, THUS POSTPONING A STRIKE.

TO AMEND H.R. 6950, INVESTMENT TAX CREDIT ACT, BY ESTABLISHING THE RULE THAT AT LEAST 75% OF THE FUNDS AVAILABLE TO A POLITICAL PARTY UNDER THE PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION CAMPAIGN FUND ACT OF 1967 MUST BE USED FOR CERTAIN SPECIFIED EXPENSES, AND NO MORE THAN 25% MAY BE SPENT ON ELECTION DAY.
TO AMEND H.R. 6950, BY PROVIDING RULES FOR PAYMENTS TO MINOR PARTIES UNDER THE PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION CAMPAIGN FUND ACT.
TO AMEND H.R. 6950, BY PROVIDING A FINE OF $10,000 OR IMPRISONMENT FOR UP TO 5 YEARS OR BOTH FOR WILLFUL MISUSE OF FUNDS RECEIVED UNDER THE PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION CAMPAIGN FUND ACT.
TO AMEND H.R. 6950, BY LIMITING THE APPLICATION OF THE PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION CAMPAIGN FUND ACT IN THE ELECTIONS OF 1968 TO ADVERTISING EXPENSES ONLY.
TO AMEND H.R. 6950, BY REPEALING THE PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION CAMPAIGN FUND ACT OF 1966 AS OF JULY 1, 1967.

TO RATIFY EXEC C, A CONVENTION DESIGNED TO INSURE THAT PARTIES INVOLVED IN A SUIT BE GIVEN TIMELY NOTICE WITH RESPECT TO JUDICIAL AND EXTRAJUDICIAL DOCUMENTS SERVED ABROAD AND TO FACILITATE INTERNATIONAL JUDICAL ASSISTANCE BY SIMPLIFYING AND EXPEDITING THE PROCEDURES FOR THAT PURPOSE.

TO AMEND H.R. 6950, BY PROVIDING A SLIDING SCALE FOR ALLOWABLE TAX CREDITS FOR PAYING COLLEGE EXPENSES.  THE TAX CREDIT WOULD BE AVAILABLE, UNDER THIS AMENDMENT, ONLY TO TAXPAYERS WITH AN ADJUSTED GROSS INCOME LESS THAN $24,000.
TO AMEND H.R. 6950, BY ALLOWING TAX CREDITS FOR THOSE INDIVIDUALS PAYING COLLEGE EXPENSES.
TO AMEND H.R. 6950, BY REDUCING EXCISE TAX ON TELEPHONES FROM 10% TO 3%, UNTIL APRIL 1, 1968, AT WHICH TIME EXCISE TAX IS SCHEDULED TO REDUCE TO 1%.
TO AMEND H.R. 6950, BY REDUCING EXCISE TAX ON AUTOMOBILES FROM 7% TO 4%, WITH A FURTHER REDUCTION TO 2% ALREADY SCHEDULED TO TAKE EFFECT MAR. 31, 1968.
TO AMEND H.R. 6950, BY AMENDING TITLE II OF SOCIAL SECURITY ACT, LOWERING FROM 62 TO 60 THE AGE AT WHICH BENEFITS MAY BE PAID.
TO RATIFY EXEC O, INTERNATIONAL TELECOMMUNICATIONS CONVENTION.

TO AMEND H.R. 6950, BY INCREASING SCOIAL SECURITY BENEFITS, TO BE PAID FOR OUT OF GENERAL REVENUE RATHER THAN SOCIAL SECURITY PAYROLL TAX.  MINIMUM BENEFITS WOULD BE RAISED FROM $44 TO $70 AND THE AVERAGE PAYMENT RAISED FROM $83.50 TO 97.70.
TO AMEND H.R. 6950, BY EXTENDING HOSPITALIZATION BENEFITS UNDER MEDICARE TO 70,000 OLDER CITIZENS WHO ARE 65 AND NOT ELIGIBLE FOR SOCIAL SECURITY OR RAILROAD RETIREMENT BENEFITS.

TO TABLE AN AMENDMENT TO H.R. 6950, WHICH REGULATES THE IMPORTING OF LIVESTOCK AND LIVESTOCK PRODUCTS; SETTING AS A LIMIT THE 5-YEAR AVERAGE OF 1958-1962, REDUCING THE ALLOWABLE LEVEL FROM 1 BILLION TO 750 MILLION POUNDS.

TO AMEND H.R. 6950, BY REGULATING THE IMPORTATION OF LIVESTOCK AND LIVESTOCK PRODUCTS; SETTING AS A LIMIT THE 5-YEAR AVERAGE OF 1958-1962, THUS REDUCING THE ALLOWABLE LEVEL FROM 1 BILLION TO 750 MILLION POUNDS.

TO AMEND H.R. 6950, BY ADDING A TITLE II, THE HONEST ELECTION ACT OF 1967, IN PLACE OF THE PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION CAMPAIGN FUND ACT OF 1966, REPEALED BY GORE AMENDMENT. TITLE II CHANGES THAT STATUTE IN CERTAIN WAYS, INCLUDING, AMONG OTHERS, INCORPORATING GUIDELINES FOR EXPENDITURE OF COMPAIGN FUNDS, REQUIRING THAT DISBURSEMENT OF FUNDS BE GIVEN NOT TO A NATIONAL PARTY COMMITTEE, BUT TO A PRESIDENTAL CANDIDATE OR HIS AGENT.  IT ALSO DEFINES A "MINOR PARTY" AS ONE WHICH RECEIVED MORE THAN 2 MILLION BUT LESS THAN 15 MILLION WOULD WOULD PERMIT DISBURSEMENT FUNDS TO THE MINOR PARTY ON BASIS OF CURRENT OR PRECEDING ELECTION, WHICHEVER SHOWED GREATEST STRENGTH OF MINOR PARTY.
TO RATIFY EXEC. D, 90TH-1, FOR THE PEACEFUL USE OF OUTER SPACE.

TO RECOMMIT H.R. 6950, WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO REPORT FORTHWITH THAT PORTION OF THE BILL DEALING WITH INVESTMENT TAX CREDIT, AND THAT PORTION WHICH REPEALS THE PRESIDENTIAL CAMPAIGN FUND ACT OF 1966 AS OF JULY 31, 1967, AND TO REPORT WITHIN 6 WEEKS ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS FOR THE PRESIDENTIAL CAMPAIGN FUND ACT. IN EFFECT,THE MATTER OF CAMPAIGN FUNDING IS DROPPED FROM CONSIDERATION IN THE SENATE UNTIL THE COMMITTEE ON FINANCE HAS FURTHER STUDIED THE BILL AND CAN SUBMIT IMPROVEMENTS TO IT.  IF THE COMMITTEE DOES NOT REPORT BY JULY 31, THE PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION CAMPAIGN FUND EXPIRES
TO TABLE AN AMENDMENT TO H.R. 6950, WHICH WOULD STRIKE SECTION 5 OF THE BILL, REPEALING THE PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION CAMPAIGN FUND ACT.

TO PASS S. 602, THE APPALACHIAN REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT ACT AMENDMENTS OF 1967, A BILL TO INCREASE HIGHWAY AUTHORIZATION, PROVIDE PLANNING GRANTS FOR HEALTH PROJECTS, ENCOURAGE MODERATE AND LOW-COST HOUSING , PROVIDE PLANNING MONEY FOR TIMBER PRODUCTS RESEARCH AND FOR DEVELOPMENT OF PROGRAMS FOR ACID MINE POLLUTION CONTROL.

TO AMEND S. 1039, AUTHORIZING POSTMASTER GENERAL TO ENTER INTO LEASES OF REAL PROPERTY, BY LIMITING THAT AUTHORITY TO THE CONSTRUCTION AND LEASING OF POST OFFICE BUILDINGS WHICH THE ADMINISTRATOR OF THE GENERAL SERVICES ADMINISTRATION DETERMINES WOULD COST LESS THAN $250,000.
TO PASS H.J. RES. 543, A FURTHER EXTENSION OF THE PERIOD PROVIDED UNDER RAILWAY LABOR ACT IN WHICH LABOR AND MANAGEMENT MUST NEGOTIATE, BEFORE A STRIKE CAN BEGIN.
TO AMEND H.R. 6950, BY DELETING SEC. 5, WHICH REPEALS THE PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION CAMPAIGN FUND ACT AS OF JULY 31, 1967.
TO RATIFY EXEC. G, 88TH-1, A CONVENTION CONCERNING THE EXCHANGE OF OFFICIAL DOCUMENTS.

TO RATIFY EXEC. A, 90-1, AMENDING THE U.N. CHARTER BY INCREASING FROM 7 TO 9 THE NUMBER OF SECURITY COUNCIL MEMBERS WHO MAY CALL, TOGETHER WITH 2/3 OF GENERAL ASSEMBLY, FOR A CONFERENCE TO REVIEW THE U.N. CHARTER.
TO RATIFY EXECUTIVE G, 90TH-1, A CONVENTION WHICH ATTEMPTS TO INSURE THAT PRODUCTION AND USE OF NARCOTIC DRUGS ARE RESTRICTED TO MEDICAL AND SCIENTIFIC PURPOSES.

TO AMEND H.R. 6950, BY PROVIDING THAT "THE PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION CAMPAIGN FUND ACT SHALL BE INOPERATIVE AFTER SEPT. 15, 1967, UNLESS CONGRESS BY LAW SHALL OTHERWISE DIRECT." (THE VICE-PRESIDENT VOTED NAY TO BREAK THE TIE.)
TO AMEND H.R. 6950 TO PROVIDE THAT NO FUNDS SHALL BE COLLECTED UNDER THE PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION CAMPAIGN FUND ACT UNTIL GUIDELINES FOR THE DISBURSEMENT OF SUCH FUNDS SHALL HAVE BEEN SET FORTH BY LAW.

TO PASS H.R. 6950, WHICH RESTORES A 7% INVESTMENT TAX CREDIT AND ALLOWANCE OF ACCELERATED DEPRECIATION IN THE CASE OF CERTAIN REAL PROPERTY, AND AS AMENDED, PROVIDES THAT NO FUNDS SHALL BE COLLECTED UNDER THE PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION CAMPAIGN FUND ACT UNTIL GUIDELINES FOR THE DISBURSEMENT OF SUCH FUNDS SHALL HAVE BEEN SET FORTH BY LAW.

TO AMEND S. 1432, THE SELECTIVE SERVICE ACT OF 1967, BY PUTTING THE SENATE ON RECORD AS FAVORING THE OBJECTIVE OF MOVING TO AN EFFECTIVE VOLUNTARY SYSTEM FOR THE PROCUREMENT OF MILITARY MANPOWER, REPLACING THE DRAFT.
TO AMEND S. 1432, BY EXTENDING THE PRESENT UNIVERSAL MILITARY TRAINING AND SERVICE ACT FOR TWO RATHER THAN FOUR YEARS.
TO AMEND S. 1432, BY MAKING SERVICE IN SOUTHEAST ASIA VOLUNTARY.
TO AMEND S. 1432, BY REDUCING THE LENGTH OF SERVICE OF DRAFTEES FROM 2 YEARS TO A MAXIMUM OF 18 MONTHS.

TO AMEND S. 1432, BY REQUIRING THE PRESIDENT TO ESTABLISH "NATIONAL CRITERIA FOR THE CLASSIFICATION OF PERSONS SUBJECT TO INDUCTION ... AND, TO THE MAXIMUM EXTENT POSSIBLE, REQUIRE SUCH CRITERIA TO BE ADMINISTERED UNIFORMLY THROUGHOUT THE UNITED STATES."
TO AMEND S. 1432, BY PROVIDING DEFERMENTS FOR PEACE CORPS AND VISTA MEMBERS.
TO AMEND S. 1432, TO ALLOW INDIVIDUALS TO BE REPRESENTED BY COUNSEL WHEN APPEARING BEFORE DRAFT BOARDS.
TO PASS S. 1432, THE SELECTIVE SERVICE ACT OF 1967.
TO RECOMMIT THE NOMINATION OF RUTHERFORD M. POOTS AS DEPUTY ADMINISTRATOR OF A.I.D.
CONFERMATION OF NOMINATION OF RUTHERFORD M. POOTS A DEPUTY ADMINISTRATOR OF A.I.D.
TO PASS H.R. 9020, DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR AND RELATED AGENCIES APPROPRIATIONS, 1968.
TO PASS H.R. 9481, SECOND SUPPLEMENTAL APPROPRIATIONS, 1967.
TO PASS H.R. 7501, TREASURY, POST OFFICE AND EXECUTIVE OFFICE APPROPRIATIONS, 1968.
TO AMEND S. 1352, ADJUSTMENTS IN OUSTANDING SILVER CERTIFICATES, BY PROVIDING THAT 165 MILLION OUNCES OF SILVER BE TRANSFERRED TO THE DEFENCE STOCKPILE IMMEDIATELY, RATHER THAN A YEAR FROM NOW.

TO AMEND S. RES. 81, A RESOLUTION TO PROVIDE A MEDIATION PROCESS FOR THE SETTLEMENT OF THE RAILWAY LABOR DISPUTE, BY INSTRUCTING THE GOVERNEMNT TO SEIZE 10% OF RAILROAD PROFITS, DURING THE PERIOD THAT DETERMINATION OF MEDIATION BOARD IS IN EFFECT, IF THE 90 DAY PROCESS OF MEDIATION SHOULD FAIL.

TO AMEND S.J. RES. 81, BY PROVIDING THAT, ON DETERMINATION BY THE PRESIDENT OF A NATIONAL EMERGENCY, THE RAILROADS MAY BE SEIZED AND RUN BY THE GOVERNMENT FOR 90 DAYS, DURING WHICH TIME LABOR AND MANAGEMENT ARE EXPECTED TO ENTER INTO NEGOTIATIONS.  AT THE END OF 90 DAYS, PROPOSALS OF THE SPECIAL MEDIATION BOARD WILL GO INTO EFFECT.
TO PASS S.J.RES. 81.
TO AMEND H.R. 2508, ESTABLISHMENT OF CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICTS, BY REDUCING FROM 35% TO 10% THE PERMISSIBLE VARIATION BETWEEN THE LARGEST AND SMALLEST CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICTS IN A STATE.
TO RECONSIDER THE PREVIOUS VOTE ON THE KENNEDY AMENDMENT TO H.R. 2508.  SEE ROLL CALL 113.

TO PASS H.R. 2508, A BILL PROVIDING FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT OF CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICTS BASED ON THE 18TH DECENNIAL AND SUBSEQUENT CENSUSES, WHICH DISTRICTS MUST BE COMPOSED OF CONTINGUOUS AND COMPACT TERRITORY.  THE DIFFERENCE IN POPULATION BETWEEN THE LARGEST AND SMALLEST DISTRICTS WITHIN A STATE MAY NOT EXCEED 10%.
TO PASS S. 1030, A BILL REVISING THE METHOD OF FINANCING THE INFORMATIONAL MEDIA GUARANTEE PROGRAM, AND CLARIFYING THE LAW RESPECTING DOMESTIC AVAILABILITY OF U.S.I.A. MATERIALS.

CONFERENCE REPORT ON S. 1432, THE SELECTIVE SERVICE ACT OF 1967.  THE SENATE ACCEPTED CERTAIN HOUSE AMENDMENTS, MAKING CONCIENTOUS OBJECTOR STATUS HARDER TO OBTAIN, AND CHANGED THE HOUSE PROPOSAL FOR "NEGATIVE VETO" OF PRESIDENTIAL LOTTERY PROPOSALS TO A REQUIREMENT THAT THE PRESIDENT MUST RECEIVE SPECIFIC AUTHORITY FROM CONGRESS FOR SUCH A PROPOSAL.

TO AMEND S. RES. 112, A RESOLUTION CENSURING SEN. THOMAS DODD, BY "ADMONISHING" THE SENATOR TO AVOID, IN THE FUTURE, CONDUCT WHICH MIGHT BE CONSTRUED "AS BEING IN DEROGATION OF THE HIGH STANDARD OF ETHICS BY WHICH A MEMBER OF THE SENATE... SHOULD BE GOVERNED."
TO AMEND S. RES. 112, BY SUBSTITUTING THE WORD "REPRIMAND" FOR THE WORD "CENSURE" WHEREVER IT APPEARS IN THE RESOLUTION.
